University of Leicester http://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. English in Education: Current National Issues - a paper by the Common English Forum http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/english-association/news-1/english-in-education The Common English Forum published today a list of their concerns about English in Education at all levels.

What are our concerns? We believe that good English teaching is under threat for a number of reasons. The pace of change in education in recent years has been considerable and seems set to continue. Much teaching and learning is at present being driven chiefly by what can be assessed and is distorted by the pressures of accountability, rather than being shaped by what is educationally desirable for pupils.

\ufffd\ufffdThe complete paper can be found here and on the Forum's website https://commonenglishforum.wordpress.com/news-events/english-in-education-current-national-issues/

]]> No publisher hl11 English English Association Education 2015-03-19T14:55:00Z Blog Entry Expressions of interest in attending http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/criminology/research/current-projects/revenge/expressions-of-interest-in-attending No publisher arj13 2015-03-19T14:53:46Z Form Folder English in Education: Current National Issues http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/english-association/news-1/english-in-education-current-national-issues The Common English Forum today publish their concerns on English in education at all levels Who are we? The Common English Forum represents all the major bodies with a professional interest in the teaching of English, from Primary level to Higher Education (a list of members is provided at the end of this document). We are committed to the furtherance of English as a subject and to fostering the highest standards in its teaching and learning.

What are our concerns? We believe that good English teaching is under threat for a number of reasons. The pace of change in education in recent years has been considerable and seems set to continue. Much teaching and learning is at present being driven chiefly by what can be assessed and is distorted by the pressures of accountability, rather than being shaped by what is educationally desirable for pupils.

At Primary level there is widespread concern among teachers that the phonics and grammar tests for 7 and 11 year-olds are inefficient and imprecise ways of assessing children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds literacy standards, to the extent of being positively harmful to our youngest childrens\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd experiences of reading. The tests which 11 year olds are required to take continue to have a negative effect in the English curriculum, particularly in Year 6 where \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdteaching to the test\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd inevitably takes place.

At Secondary level the recent reforms to GCSE examination introduced in the name of making both assessment and demand more rigorous are leading to an unforeseen and undesirable narrowing of the curriculum as early as KS3. As schools begin to \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdteach to the test\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd as early as Year 9 or even before, there will be an impoverishment in pupils\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd experience of both reading and writing. The study of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcanonical\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd texts is important, but its new prominence devalues other forms of literary and linguistic experience. Pupils will have much less time for \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdreading for pleasure\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, and they will thereby be deprived of access to the range of high-quality writing which exists for children and young adults. The exclusion of media and multi-modal texts, and the reduced emphasis on speaking and listening threaten to deprive pupils of skills and knowledge which are vital in the contemporary world. The absence of any kind of coursework assessment at GCSE also restricts pupils\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd opportunities for the independent work, personal research and extended writing, which are essential to undergraduate study and future employability.

At Advanced level, the decoupling of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAS\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd poses acute logistical problems for schools and colleges. Whilst Cambridge University has issued advice to schools advocating the retention of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAS\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd for all, the new system is not designed to serve this purpose. The full ramifications of the current reforms have been so far inadequately understood.

In the training and recruitment of teachers, there is currently a shortage of graduates with a specialist qualification in English. Recently introduced arrangements surrounding the training of teachers are fundamentally incoherent, involving different routes, sometimes leading to different qualifications, and embodying different aims and different experiences. The application process is complex and confusing. The current situation needs rationalisation.

In short, initiatives have been introduced quickly. They have involved major upheavals and are now issuing in unforeseen consequences. We think that at this time there is need for policy-makers to develop a coherent overview of the position of English in schools and universities. Fresh policy for any new government needs to be based on a full awareness of all the issues involved either in the further implementation or in the halting of these reforms.

]]> No publisher hl11 2015-03-19T14:51:54Z Page 'Fields of flowers \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a visit to western Sichuan, China' http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/march/fields-of-flowers-2013-a-visit-to-western-sichuan-china Knoll House in the Botanic Garden - 25 Mar 2015, 10:30AM - 11:30AM Some of the great plant hunters of the 19th and 20th centuries travelled in China and in particular in Western Sichuan, from where they brought back to Europe a range of exciting new plants.\ufffd\ufffd This illustrated talk will show a variety of plants in their native habitats, high in the mountains, in a region adjacent to Tibet.\ufffd\ufffd This proximity to Tibet means that many of the people share the Tibetan culture and this is shown in the appearance of their houses and religious buildings.

To be given by Dr Mary Walmsley on Wednesday 25 March at 10.30am at the Knoll House in the Botanic Garden.

Please park on Glebe Road, and enter the Knoll through the main door off the driveway. Non-members of the Friends are welcome too (\ufffd\ufffd2 each).

Refreshments will be served in the Knoll before and afterwards. Booking will not be necessary, and we hope that you can find time to drop in and join us.

]]> No publisher pt91 Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff Event:Lecture 2015-03-25T10:30:00Z UoL Event History of Seismology Meeting http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2015/april/history-of-seismology-meeting College Court - 9 & 10 April 2015 A meeting to be held at College Court, University of Leicester, UK on the 9th and 10th April 2015 Sponsored by the British Geophysical Association, the History of Physics Group of the Institute of Physics, the Royal Astronomical Society, the Geological Society, Guralp Systems plc, Ophir Energy plc, and Shell Global Solutions, BV.

Full Registration ends on 20th March 2015

Registration can be completed at http://shop.le.ac.uk

(Hover and then click over 'Conferences & Events - Leicester Conferences - Geology')

The full programme, abstracts, speaker biographies and further meeting information can be accessed via News and Events \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd History of Seismology Meeting in the adjoining Navigation pane.

The UK has a rich history in the science of Seismology, and it is just over 100 years since the death of John Milne, the man who introduced the word \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdseismometer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd to the science. At a time when major facets of the subject are being, perhaps have been superseded - for example onshore controlled source crustal seismology by passive seismic methods - and so are becoming \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhistorical\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, this meeting has been designed to explore the UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds contribution to Seismology. While science does not recognize national boundaries, the seismological work that has been undertaken in the UK since at least the time of Robert Hooke and the founding of the Royal Society is peculiarly amenable to presentation at an Institute of Physics History of Physics Group sponsored meeting.

The meeting has been divided into four sessions; Earthquakes, Instruments and Institutions, Controlled Source Seismology and Crustal Studies, and Passive Seismology. To ensure the content is not just a reflection of science past, the sessions include topics that highlight outstanding current work, and speakers have been asked to consider future trends in their particular field.

Twenty-two speakers will cover such varied topics as Early British Thinking on Earthquakes, Prediction, Quiet Earthquakes, Test-ban Verification, Schools\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Seismology, Seismic Investigations of the Ocean Floor, Seismology and the Oil and Gas Industry, Tomography and the Outer Earth, Anisotropy, Interferometry and Seismic Noise, Helioseismology, and more.

The meeting will take place over two days, posters being displayed throughout. There will be a conference dinner. The accompanying person programme will include a visit to the Richard III exhibition and tomb, if there is demand.

Registration can be completed at http://shop.le.ac.uk

(Hover and then click over 'Conferences & Events - Leicester Conferences - Geology')

Full Registration ends on 20th March 2015

]]> No publisher pt91 Event:Conference Magazine:Research College:SciEng Magazine:Staff 2015-04-08T23:00:00Z UoL Event Spotlight to be shone on UK women in reggae http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/march/spotlight-to-be-shone-on-uk-women-in-reggae Student to create film documentary on the unsung reggae heroes of the music industry as part of his PhD Donald Harper, a PhD student in the School of Management and music industry veteran, will be shining a light on a group of unsung heroes\ufffd\ufffdfrom the UK music industry by producing a film documentary as part of his PhD. \ufffd\ufffd

The documentary will cover reggae artists such as Carroll Thompson, Janet Kay and Lorna Gee - artists who created unforgettable sounds between the 1950s and 1980s but never received the universal recognition they deserved.

Up to a dozen artists have agreed to be part of\ufffd\ufffdthe documentary, which has the theme of:\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWhither Jamaica\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Music Industry? Learning from strategic failures to harness and organise a cultural resource for economic development.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

He said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdI hope to use the documentary to help develop some kind of policy for reggae music both in Jamaica and the UK, where the lover\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds rock genre began. The Jamaican government recognises that reggae is something they need to support, but much of this is nothing more than rhetoric."

Harper's roots lie in the reggae music industry. The founder of Jamstar Productions, an entertainment marketing firm that has worked with some of Jamaica\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds premier artists, Harper has worked across the world supporting names such as the Skatalites, Chakademus & Pliers, Diana King, Nadine Sutherland, Patra and Lady Saw.

The\ufffd\ufffddocumentary will have a Birmingham dimension as the city\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds own reggae star Yaz Alexander is helping him with research material. Damien \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLil D\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Morgan, the city\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds well-known rapper, will produce the documentary through his video company Dynamexx Enterprise.

Harper has applied to the Heritage Lottery Fund for help in making the documentary and a crowd funding initiative is being planned through Buzzbnk.org. He is also hopeful that sponsors will come forward.

Anyone wanting more details can visit the website or email Harper at info@womeninreggae.org.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Management Magazine:Student 2015-03-19T14:16:24Z Blog Entry Ceremony to mark the departure of Richard III\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds mortal remains from the University of Leicester http://www2.le.ac.uk/staff/announcements/ceremony-to-mark-the-departure-of-richard-iii2019s-mortal-remains-from-the-university-of-leicester Staff, students and their families invited to historic occasion A brief ceremony to mark the departure of the mortal remains of King Richard III from the University campus on Sunday 22 March.\ufffd\ufffd Those wishing to witness this historic occasion should gather on the lawn in front of the Fielding Johnson Building\ufffd\ufffdor along Mayor\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Walk (see campus map)\ufffd\ufffdby 10.30am.\ufffd\ufffd The Service will begin at 10.50am and end at approximately\ufffd\ufffd11.40am. Parking will not be available on\ufffd\ufffdsite so please travel to the campus by bus or on foot.

]]> No publisher pt91 2015-03-19T13:59:45Z Blog Entry Three New Research Degree Funding Opportunities Available http://www2.le.ac.uk/projects/migration-research-group/news-and-events/three-new-research-degree-funding-opportunities-available Research Degree Funding opportunities are currently available for one fully-funded PhD studentships, and two Graduate Research Assistantships. \ufffd\ufffd

The Department of Politics and International Relations is pleased to announce that it is currently offering the following migration-related research degree funding opportunities:

1 x Fully-Funded PhD Studentship in Comparative Politics

1 x Graduate Research Assistantship in Politics/ Mathematics - Analysis of Migrant Organisational Networks in Europe

The Department of Sociology and the School of History is pleased to offer a funded Graduate Research Assistantship for September 2015 entry to their Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) programme:

1 x Graduate Research Assistantship in Sociology and History - Deportation and Detention in Comparative Historical Perspective.

]]> No publisher an201 2015-03-19T13:45:00Z Blog Entry Leicester secures a Rugby Varsity double http://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/march/leicester-secures-a-rugby-varsity-double-against-de-montfort-university Success for Leicester teams at Welford Road on Wednesday 18 March The University of Leicester's women and men's\ufffd\ufffdRugby\ufffd\ufffdteams have secured a double Varsity victory over players from De Montfort University during matches played on Wednesday 18 March.

Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds women recorded eight tries in a 45-3 win while the men made sure of the double with a 22-8 victory in front of a large and passionate crowd at the home of the Leicester Tigers.

The women, looking for their 12th consecutive Varsity victory kicked things off and looked in serious mood early on, opening up a 17-point lead in the first quarter of an hour. After running in four tries in the first half to go in with a 22-3 lead, they continued their dominance in the second, scoring the same number of tries. Captain Jessica Wells, Emily Varnals and Anna Stephenson all claimed two apiece to preserve their 12-year unbeaten streak as the game ended 45-3.

University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds men's team celebrate securing a Varsity double
After a tight start to the men\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds game, where the score stood at 3-3 after a penalty each for both sides, two first half tries in quick succession from Josh Finch and Jack Arundell saw the University of Leicester take control of the contest.\ufffd\ufffdAnother try from Arundell after a flowing move extended the lead to 22-3 at the break.

The second half was a tense and low-scoring affair, with the only try coming from De Montfort University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Michael Agyei. It proved to be too little too late as Leicester held on in the final stages to secure a 22-8 victory, extending their annual head-to-head lead to 8-4.

The two victories stretched Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Varsity lead to 20-6 over DMU as of Wednesday evening, with around 17 games still left to play.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Sports Magazine:Student 2015-03-19T13:40:00Z Blog Entry Call for nominations: Celebrating best practice in technical services http://www2.le.ac.uk/staff/community/notice-board/2015/march/call-for-nominations-celebrating-best-practice-in-technical-services Inaugural Papin Prizes to be awarded for demonstrating excellent practice Do you know a technician whose work goes above and beyond? ]]> No publisher pt91 2015-03-19T13:36:32Z Blog Entry Self Service portal to be withdrawn on Friday 27 March 2015 http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/about/news/self-service-withdrawl-2015-03-27 The IT Self Service portal will be withdrawn on Friday 27 March 2015. Instead, forms are available on the IT Help website for standard requests. Previously, staff could use the Self Service portal to contact the IT Service Desk for standard requests or when the IT Service Desk was closed. The Self Service portal will now be withdrawn.

You can use forms on the IT Help website to make standard requests from Friday 27 March 2015. A new tool will be provided soon to improve the user experience.

Short Course IT accounts

You can use this form to request University IT accounts for courses you are running:

  • Request short course IT accounts

Use ALICE

If you have a project that needs to use ALICE High Performance computing, you can follow these steps and fill out the request form:

  • Request access to ALICE

Need to check the status of your IT Support Request?

If you want to get more information about an open Support Request with IT Services, call the IT Service Desk on 0116 252 2253.

]]> No publisher rfg15 IT Services - Service status 2015-03-19T13:35:00Z Page Change the target destination of a shortcut http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/ithelp/my-computer/files-and-security/faq/faq-change-the-target-destination-of-a-shortcut
  • Right click on the file and choose Properties

  • Under Target: enter the new location where you want the shortcut to point to

    • Change the Target: from cfs.le.ac.uk to uol.le.ac.uk

  • Click Ok
    • ]]>     No publisher rfg15 2015-03-19T13:35:00Z Page     EN2080 Advanced Creative Writing Skills http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/english/undergraduate/creating-writing-pathway/test-2 \ufffd\ufffd

    Course details

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Creative Writing, Year 2, Semester 2
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Credits: 20
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Pre-requisites: EN1025, EN1035, EN2070
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Convener: Dr. Harry Whitehead
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Course code: EN2080

    Module aims

    This module aims to combine an intensive creative writing workshop with practice in performing your work, and advanced study of creative writing research methods, critical reflection, and writing literary reviews for publication. The different strands will feed into each other at all points through the semester.

    Content

    This module includes various strands: creative writing workshops; performance workshops; lectures on research for writers, advanced practical critical reflection, and writing literary reviews for publication. Students will continue to keep a writing journal - begun in the first semester - that will feed the assessed critical essay. The module will also involve lectures, workshops and autonomous small group work on developing personal performance techniques for your own work. Note that performance does not always involve dramatic expression: there are many writers who speak quietly, undemonstratively yet effectively. This module will help you find your own best way to express your work in performance.

    Learning and teaching

    The module will be delivered in ten weekly lectures and ten weekly workshops

    Lectures may include:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd discussions of creative craft issues, techniques, forms and genres, as well as research methods, reflection on one\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds own work, and writing literary reviews for publication
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd talks by established writers in the School of English discussing their own writing practice
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a lecture on performing creative work in public
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd readings and discussions by visiting writers

    Workshops may consist of:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd creative writing peer review sessions
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd creative writing exercises
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a performance workshop (or workshops)
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd mini-lectures
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd small and large group discussions on any of the module\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds topics

    Learning outcomes

    Subject knowledge:

    After completing this module, learners should be able to:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd apply established research methods in Creative Writing Studies to their own practice
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd evaluate existing writing to write critical reviews in literary journal and newspaper styles
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd construct creative work in different forms and genres with a sound understanding of craft elements that may be used
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd apply craft skills learned on previous modules and this one in the construction of creative work
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd perform their creative work in public with confidence
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd identify key issues in improving the performance of their creative work
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd analyse and provide constructive feedback about their own and other's creative work

    Transferable skills:

    By the end of the module, students should be able to:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd write, using techniques they have acquired, in different forms, genres and contexts
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd effectively communicate ideas through different kinds of narratives
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd reflect critically on their own and other\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds work
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd write critical reviews of creative work in newspaper and popular journal styles
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd present their own work in a public arena with confidence

    Assessment

    There are three elements to the assessment:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Creative Writing (45%): 2000 words (or equivalent) in any creative writing form (poetry, prose, narrative non-fiction, script or drama).

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Critical Work (45%) in two parts: 1) a 1500 word essay on any issue or issues related to creative writing research and reflection, using information from the writing journal you have kept throughout the year; 2) a 500 word literary review of any book or performance by a guest author appearing in the past year at the university. Please note: your writing journal will be submitted as an Appendix for reference (though not assessed summatively itself).

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Oral Presentation (10%): a five minute performance of your own work, performed in a group environment.

    ]]>     No publisher ar395 2015-03-19T13:34:16Z Page     EN2070 Using Stories http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/english/undergraduate/creating-writing-pathway/test-1 EN2070 USING STORIES

    Course details

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Creative Writing, Year 2, Semester 1
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Credits: 20
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Pre-requisites: EN1025 and EN1035
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Convener: Dr. Jonathan Taylor
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Course code: EN2070

    Module aims

    This Creative Writing module aims to explore some of the ways in which writers can discover, recover and explore materials, ideas and narratives in the wider world, and use and reshape them into effective creative pieces. It encourages students to develop their Creative Writing research methods, and then to employ those methods in the construction of original writing, in multiple forms and genres. In this way, it aims to enhance both the students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd research and writing skills.

    Content

    This module includes various strands, all of which concern the relationship between the workshop and materials, ideas and narratives in the wider world.

    Topics may include:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Using historical stories
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Using place-based subject-matter
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Using other art-forms
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Using scientific concepts
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Using libraries and museums

    Forms and genres covered in the creative exploration of these topics may include:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Fiction and historical fiction
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Creative non-fiction
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Scriptwriting
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Poetry (including ekphrastic and found)
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Site-specific writing
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Speculative fiction

    As well as practical creative writing exercises, students will be encouraged to think critically and reflectively about the topics covered.

    Learning and teaching

    The module will be delivered in ten weekly lectures and ten weekly seminars

    Lectures may include:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd discussions by staff of relevant craft issues, techniques, genres, and research methods
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd talks by established writers in the School of English discussing their own practice in using research to construct creative work
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd presentations on particular research topics by invited experts
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd screenings
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd readings and discussions by visiting writers

    Seminars may consist of:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd creative writing workshop exercises
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd feedback sessions
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd exploration of particular subjects relating to writing craft and research topics
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd mini-lectures on particular research topics
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd discussions of reflective and critical work

    All students will be allotted an Autonomous Learning Group (ALG). Each small group of students will decide on the location for a field visit (vetted by the tutor), undertake the visit (as a group or individually), meet to discuss material gathered, before individually using that material to construct a creative work in their chosen form. Students will also keep a writing journal throughout their second year creative writing modules (i.e. this module and the second semester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdResearch, Reflection and Review: an Advanced Creative Writing Workshop\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd).

    Learning outcomes

    Subject knowledge:

    After completing this module, learners should be able to:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd effectively formulate creative ideas from research conducted in the wider world
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd evaluate and select which genre will prove most effective to realise the creative idea
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd construct creative work in a variety of different genres using that research
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd apply craft skills learned on previous modules and this one in the construction of that creative work
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd critically and constructively evaluate the success or otherwise such research in creative practice

    Transferable skills:

    By the end of the module, students should be able to:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd write, using techniques they have acquired, in different forms, genres and contexts
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd effectively communicate ideas through different kinds of narratives
    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd reflect critically on their work

    Assessment

    There are two elements to the assessment:

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Creative Work: 3000 words or equivalent, depending on form using a particular piece of specified research in any accepted Creative Writing form (poetry, prose, narrative non-fiction, script or drama) [Summative, to be submitted with the Reflective Commentary] (70% of whole)

    \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Reflective Commentary: 1000 words focussing on how the research was used, and technical/craft issues raised in doing so [Summative, to be submitted with the Creative Work] (30% of whole)

    ]]>     No publisher ar395 2015-03-19T13:33:53Z Page     Creative Writing Pathway http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/english/undergraduate/creating-writing-pathway/creative-writing-pathway Creative Writing Creative Writing Pathway

    At the end of the first year, students who have taken the Year One option, EN1025/1035 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIntroduction to Writing Creatively,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd may decide to continue with Creative Writing as a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdminor pathway\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (i.e. to constitute a third of their overall degree).

    In Year Two, students take the modules EN2070 Using Stories in the first semester, and EN2080 Advanced Creative Writing Skills. Click on the links to see details of these modules.

    In Year Three, students select special subjects taught by tutors in their own specialist forms. Please click here Creative Writing Courses to see some existing Creative Writing special subjects (please note, these may change from year to year).

    ]]>     No publisher ar395 2015-03-19T13:33:43Z Page
